awd_titl_txt: Connections in the Making: Elementary Students, Teachers, and STEM Professionals Integrating Science and Engineering to Design Community Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM). This project will develop and study community-connected, integrated science and engineering curriculum units that leverage mobile maker space and digital notebook technologies to support diverse elementary students' science and engineering ideas, practices, and attitudes. Students will develop prototypes and share solutions to a design challenge rooted in their local community while exploring scientific explanations of related phenomena. The integrated units will be co-developed and enacted through a collaboration of science and engineering education researchers from two local universities, teachers and administrators from two local school districts, and STEM professionals from Boston's public transportation system. This collaboration will promote integrated learning experiences and will not only support disciplinary ideas and practices but also increase students' career interests and recognition of the transformative ways in which science and engineering can address challenges in their own communities. 

A design-based research approach with an embedded curriculum comparison study will advance knowledge about mechanisms through which community and disciplinary connections support diverse elementary school student competence, motivation, and persistence in science and engineering. Data will be collected through three cycles of design involving 1,440 elementary students and 36 elementary teachers to investigate ways to improve the capacity to teach and learn through integrated science and engineering units in a community-connected way. Outcomes from this project will provide a model for curriculum development and implementation that will be unique in positioning teachers, district leaders, and STEM professionals as valued contributors in crafting and enacting integrated science and engineering curricula. It will also promote the utility of partnerships as vehicles for broadening participation of students and teachers from socioeconomically and culturally diverse public school districts. Beyond the impact on project participants, information from this study will be disseminated through pre-service teacher education courses, teacher induction networks, and in-service professional development. Project outputs, including curriculum units, curriculum development framework, and student work samples will be shared with educators both through school-district online portals and through university-hosted online collections of curriculum resources. The professional networks of the teachers, district leaders, and STEM professionals will be leveraged to raise awareness of these resources.

por.por_cntn:
The ConnecTions in the Making project team collaborated with educators from two culturally diverse school districts to develop, enact, and study six upper elementary-school curriculum units that integrate science and engineering through community-connected problem-solving. All six units can be downloaded from the project website: https://sites.google.com/view/wendell-lab/projects/community-based-engineering/connections. These curriculum units serve as exemplars for other educators and curriculum developers who wish to connect science, engineering, and community contexts for student learning toward the NGSS disciplinary core ideas and practices. In addition to online publication of detailed curriculum guides for these six units, the project produced Design Keeper, a digital engineering design notebooking tool for use by elementary students; created an open-response assessment task that characterizes students' design thinking practices; and published a series of rich qualitative analyses showcasing the details of student resources and practices for decision making and sensemaking in engineering. These tools and publications advance the conversation about how curricular tasks and instructional practices can ensure that engineering design challenges enable elementary students to build not just prototypes but also knowledge. 

The body of scholarly work produced by the project focused on the fine-grained, moment-to-moment details of how elementary students enact engineering design practices during community-connected and science-integrated curriculum units. Taken together, the project's publications demonstrate the power of microethnographic research in elementary science and engineering classrooms. Their findings reveal (a) the diverse and sophisticated array of social and intellectual resources that young learners can bring to bear in community-connected engineering design learning experiences, and (b) how features of the classroom environment and instructional moves mediate when and how students activate those resources. 

Our close analyses of classroom interactions and artifacts are impacting the field of engineering education by deepening educators' understandings of what it looks like when students engage in productive decision-making and sense-making discourse. For example, one analysis produced a "Design Zones" framework for tracking elementary students' unique and nonlinear pathways through the engineering design process. It showed how a student team moved back and forth through the four zones of Ideation, Creation, Evaluation, and Decision as they worked to construct and test a prototype for an accessible playground design problem. Another analysis resulted in a case study that can help educators better understand the demands for elementary students of giving feedback on peers' design prototypes. Intense disagreements among one student team while giving mid-design feedback helped made explicit the underlying tensions that elementary students experience during the peer feedback process in engineering design lessons. The students struggled with the perception that they must choose between being honest and being kind and between evaluating the current design and its future potential form. The dilemmas posed by the two tensions are valuable to students' developing understandings of what it means to participate collaboratively in engineering design.

Project outcomes also include direct impact on elementary student and teacher learning experiences. The ConnecTions in the Making project team directly supported over 600 elementary students in learning science and engineering, and hundreds of additional students were impacted by the project as their teachers continue to implement the curriculum units without direct support from the project team. Over 30 teachers across two districts fully participated in the project's week-long summer professional development and school-year curriculum enactment cycles. Additional teachers in each district were impacted through half-day or full-day supplemental workshops on the ConnecTions curriculum units. Over 60 additional elementary teachers gained experience with community-connected engineering learning through the use of ConnecTions curriculum materials in graduate courses offered by Tufts University and University of Massachusetts Boston.
